DOC.HEAD: Winter Storms in the West, the Midwest and the South
DOC.TEXT: Storms dumped snow, freezing rain or rain on sections of the West, the Midwest and the South on Friday as winds gusted to more than 60 mph in Northern California. Snow fell in Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, Nebraska, Wyoming, the Dakotas, Montana, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Michigan and Nebraska also received freezing rain. In six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST, 9 inches of snow fell in Flagstaff, Ariz.; 2 inches in Houghton Lake, Mount Clemens and Saginaw, Mich.; and 1 inch in Marquette and Oscoda, Mich. New Mexico's Sacramento Mountains received 8 inches of snow. Ruidoso and Cloudcroft each received about 4 inches. Winter storm warnings, winter storm watches or snow advisories were up in parts of Arizona, California, New Mexico, Ohio, New York and Pennsylvania. Rain fell on Indiana, Illinois, Missouri, Kansas, Kentucky, Tennessee and Mississippi. Heavier rainfall in the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 1.36 inch in Lafayette, La; .89 inch in Paducah, Ky. and .68 inch in Baton Rouge, La. Winds gusted over 60 mph in higher elevations near San Francisco Bay and at some of the higher summits of the Sierra Nevada in the morning. High-wind warnings were issued for the Yosemite National Park area. Friday was the 22nd day in a row the temperature in Portland, Maine, had not exceeded 32 degrees. It was the longest stretch of freezing temperatures in the city's 50 years of record-keeping. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states Friday morning was recorded in Grand Forks, N.D., where it was 17 degrees below zero. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 5 degrees below zero in Caribou and Limestone, Maine, to 81 degrees in Kingsville, Texas.
